all_citations.claim: GiveLight Foundation holds a Charity Navigator score of 94.66666666666667/100 and operates programs in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh.

The organization accepts general donations and sadaqah to support its global orphanages.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: GiveLight Foundation earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial health and transparency, balanced against a medium impact score that reflects the high costs associated with direct residential care.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact data resulting in a medium data confidence level.
Direct provision model leads to a relatively high cost per beneficiary of $1,377.81.

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 31/50, the charity offers a medium fit for donors interested in domestic and international poverty alleviation [1]. Donors can support these efforts through general charitable giving and sadaqah [3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization maintains a high Charity Navigator score of 94.66666666666667/100, reflecting strong financial accountability [1]. While it successfully directs 88.7% to programs, the impact score of 27/50 reflects the high-cost nature of direct provision, with an estimated cost per beneficiary of $1,377.81 [1][2].

strengths: High program expense ratio of 88.7%, ensuring the vast majority of funds reach beneficiaries.

In the most recent fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $2,186,834 to support its mission of building family-like environments for vulnerable children [2].

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 88.7%</cite> and a <cite id="5">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, maximizing the impact of every donation.
GiveLight holds an <cite id="6">overall score of 94.94.66666666666667/100 from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting strong governance and transparency.
The foundation demonstrates extreme fiscal stability with <cite id="7">135.0 months of working capital</cite> available to sustain operations during economic downturns.

strengths_deep_dive: GiveLight Foundation's financial health is characterized by its ability to direct <cite id="3">88.7% of its expenses toward programs</cite>, a rare feat among international relief organizations. This is supported by an <cite id="5">exceptional fundraising efficiency</cite> where it costs the organization nothing to raise a dollar. Furthermore, the organization has built a massive safety net, maintaining <cite id="7">135.0 months of working capital</cite> in reserve, which is significantly higher than the industry standard. This financial cushion ensures that the children in their care are protected from funding fluctuations. Their governance is equally strong, with an <cite id="8">Accountability & Finance beacon score of 94</cite> and a <cite id="9">perfect 100 in Leadership & Adaptability</cite> from Charity Navigator.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 2004, GiveLight Foundation is a dedicated crisis relief organization that provides long-term care and loving homes for orphaned children displaced by natural disasters and extreme circumstances. The organization operates on a global scale, establishing sustainable orphanages and family-like environments in countries including <cite id="1">Indonesia, Bangladesh, Cambodia, Sri Lanka, Morocco, and Pakistan</cite>. In the most recent fiscal year, GiveLight reported <cite id="2">total revenue of $2,186,834</cite>, which is utilized to fund its core programs: orphanage construction, education support, and direct sponsorship. The foundation distinguishes itself through an exceptionally lean financial model, reporting a <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 88.7%</cite> in its most recent filings, ensuring that every dollar of public contribution is directed toward the care of vulnerable children. Beyond immediate relief, GiveLight focuses on <cite id="4">building beautiful homes</cite> that prioritize the long-term emotional and educational needs of orphans, aiming to break the cycle of poverty through stable upbringing and academic empowerment.
